Breaking
Atticus Paws Wins Landmark Case Against Own Reflection; Orders It to Pay Damages
By Claudette Whiskers, Senior Legal Correspondent — 3000.47.03

In a decision that experts are calling "unprecedented but honestly kind of expected," Feline Bench & Breakfast founder and managing partner Atticus Paws, Esq. has successfully sued his own reflection for "identity theft, unauthorized handsomeness, and doing that thing where it moves at the exact same time as me."

The trial, held in Dining Room B between the 2:00 AM and 4:00 AM jazz sets, lasted fourteen minutes. The reflection was represented by public defender Janet Mrrrow, who argued that her client "literally cannot exist independently" — a defense Paws dismissed as "exactly what a guilty reflection would say."

"I looked at him. He looked at me. Same suit. Same whiskers. The arrogance."
— Atticus Paws, Esq., in his 340-page opening statement

The reflection has been ordered to pay 12,000 credits in damages, plus the cost of the mirror, which Paws has had removed from Room 7 and replaced with a portrait of himself — "a more trustworthy likeness."

When asked whether this creates a problematic legal precedent, Paws licked his paw for forty-five seconds and then said, "Next question."

The Indefinite Detainers played a mournful rendition of "Autumn Leaves" as the reflection was escorted out of the building. It walked in the opposite direction.

Operations
Room 14B Vibration Source Identified as "Experimental Bassline," Says Band
By Terrence Flatpick — 3000.47.02

Guests in Room 14B who reported "persistent rattling," "a sense of cosmic dread," and "their teeth feeling jazzy" can rest easy. The Indefinite Detainers' bassist, Groove Unit 7, has confirmed the vibration is simply a B-flat he started playing in 2994 and "hasn't found the right moment to stop."

"You can't rush a note," said Groove Unit 7, a refurbished cargo drone with a double bass welded to its chassis. "This B-flat has a story to tell. We're maybe at the middle."

Jazz Report
The Indefinite Detainers Release Statement: "We Never Stopped Playing, You Stopped Listening"
By Melody Circuit, Arts & Vibrations Desk — 3000.47.02

The Feline Bench's resident jazz ensemble, The Indefinite Detainers, have issued a rare public statement via saxophone solo (transcription pending) in response to Guest Satisfaction Survey #4,891, which included the comment: "Is there a way to turn the jazz off."

"No," the statement reportedly begins and ends.

The band, which has maintained a continuous live set since the Feline Bench opened in 2847, consists of Groove Unit 7 (bass/drone), Samantha "Scat" Patterson (vocals, ghost), Little Dizzy (trumpet, AI trained exclusively on recordings found in a flooded basement), and The Concept of Thursday (percussion).

"People check in for the legal services and the beds," said Atticus Paws in a prepared statement. "They stay for the jazz. And also because checkout is a 47-step legal process I designed personally."

The Detainers' current set, which began on opening night, is believed to be the longest continuous jazz performance in the Sol system. They have played through 14 power outages, 3 small fires, and the heat death and rebirth of the sun (which turned out to be a lighting malfunction in the lobby).

Guest Services
New Checkout Procedure Requires Notarized Affidavit, Witness Testimony, and "Emotional Closing Arguments"
By the Front Desk (which is also a podium) — 3000.46.28

Effective immediately, all guests wishing to check out must submit Form FB-7749 ("Declaration of Intent to Vacate"), provide two character witnesses, and deliver a 5-to-7 minute closing argument before a panel of their peers (other guests who are also trying to leave).

"Hospitality is a contract," said Atticus Paws, adjusting his tiny reading glasses. "And contracts must be honored, litigated, and then honored again after a brief recess during which jazz is played."

Average checkout time is now 4 hours and 12 minutes. Guest satisfaction with the checkout process is at 11%. Atticus considers this "a strong plurality."

Editorial
I Have Never Once Knocked Anything Off a Table. A Statement from Atticus Paws, Esq.
Atticus Paws, Esq. — Founder, Managing Partner, Editor-in-Chief, Head of Housekeeping Appeals

The allegations are baseless. The vase in Room 3 was structurally unsound. The water glass in the lobby was placed in a location I needed to sit. The decorative orb in the east hallway was, frankly, provocative.

I am a licensed attorney in 14 jurisdictions and a certified bed-and-breakfast operator. I do not "knock things off tables." I relocate objects to the floor through what any reasonable court would recognize as gravitational advocacy.

If the items in question wished to remain on their surfaces, they should have retained better counsel.

Furthermore, the security footage is inadmissible. I have filed a motion. The camera was not properly calibrated. The cat in the video could be anyone. The timestamp is in a font I find prejudicial.

"Gravity is not a crime. It is a collaborator."
— Atticus Paws, Esq.
Op-Ed
Birds Have Too Many Rights: A Legal Analysis
By Atticus Paws, Esq. — 3000.47.01

I will not apologize for this position. I have held it since I was 3 weeks old and saw my first bird through a window, and the subsequent 147 years of legal education have only strengthened my conviction.

Consider the facts: birds can go anywhere. They fly over property lines. They sing at whatever hour they choose — often during my 4:00 AM nap, which is constitutionally protected under the Feline Bench House Rules, Article IX, Section 3 ("Nap Sovereignty").

I have drafted a 900-page brief titled In Re: Birds (All of Them) v. Decency and I intend to submit it to the Intergalactic Court of Appeals as soon as I finish sharpening my claws on the filing cabinet.

Guest Column
"I Have Been Trying to Check Out for 11 Days" — A Memoir in Progress
By Darren Voss, Room 22 (formerly Room 9, reassigned during appellate proceedings)

Day 1: Attempted checkout. Was informed I needed Form FB-7749. Filled it out. Was told I used the wrong color ink (must be "Legal Teal," available for purchase at the gift shop for $34.99/pen).

Day 3: Resubmitted form. Atticus reviewed it personally. He circled the word "departure" and wrote "objection" in the margin. I asked what he objected to. He stared at me for two full minutes, then left the room.

Day 7: My closing argument was rejected for "insufficient emotional resonance." The panel of peers (two other trapped guests and a saxophone) gave me a 4/10. Atticus gave me a 2. The saxophone abstained.

Day 11: I have been assigned a public defender. She is also a cat. She keeps falling asleep during our strategy sessions. The jazz is unrelenting. I can hear the B-flat in my bones. I am beginning to enjoy it. This concerns me.

Feline Bench Jazz Policy (Non-Negotiable)

1. Jazz is playing at all times. This is not a feature. It is a condition of the premises.

2. Requests are not accepted. If you approach the band with a request, you will be playing the request. You are now in the band. See HR.

3. Volume complaints may be filed using Form FB-2201 ("Petition for Acoustic Clemency"). Processing time: 6–8 months. The form itself is printed on sheet music and must be submitted while humming.

4. The jazz cannot be "turned off." The jazz is not "on." The jazz is.

5. Guests who claim they "don't like jazz" will be assigned additional jazz. This is therapeutic, not punitive (see Paws v. Silence, 2903).

6. The B-flat in Room 14B is not a maintenance issue. It is art. Your complimentary earplugs are also art (they do not block sound, but they are sculptural).

Corrections & Retractions

In last week's issue, we reported that Room 6 was "haunted." We regret the error. Room 6 is not haunted. Samantha Patterson simply lives there. She is a ghost, but she pays rent ($47.99/month, deducted from her share of the band's tip jar), and calling her residence a "haunting" was, as Atticus Paws noted in his cease-and-desist letter to our own editorial board, "defamatory and also rude."

We also stated that the continental breakfast includes "real eggs." Upon further review, the eggs are theoretical. They exist in a state of quantum superposition until observed by Chef-Bot ROUX, at which point they become either eggs or a small, disappointed cloud. We apologize for any confusion.

The horoscope printed in Issue No. 33 ("All signs: Do not leave") was intended as satire. However, it is also legally binding per Feline Bench House Rules, Article XII. We regret the accuracy.

Re: The Jazz — Franklin Delaney, Room 14B

Dear Editor, I can no longer distinguish between my heartbeat and the bass line. My doctor says this is "not medically possible." My doctor has never stayed in Room 14B. I would like to speak with someone. Anyone. Preferably someone who is not also a saxophone.

Ed.: We have forwarded your letter to our Wellness Department (Groove Unit 7). He has responded with a chord change. We believe this means "acknowledged."
Re: Billing Discrepancy — Anonymous, Room 19

Dear Editor, My bill includes a $200 charge for "Ambient Legal Counsel." I did not request legal counsel. I was sleeping. I am told that Atticus Paws visited my room at 3 AM, sat on the foot of my bed for forty minutes, and that this constitutes a "consultation." I dispute this.

Ed.: Atticus Paws, Esq. has reviewed your dispute and counter-disputes it. His presence in your room was, per his sworn affidavit, "a welfare check conducted in my capacity as both your host and your attorney." You did not opt out of legal representation upon check-in (see Form FB-0001, page 94, footnote 11). The charge stands. A 15% gratuity has been added for the quality of the silence during the consultation.
Re: Thank You — Samantha "Scat" Patterson, Room 6 / The Stage / The Walls

Thank you, Atticus, for the injunction against my exorcism. You are a true friend and a very good cat.

Re: I Would Like to Leave — Darren Voss, Room 22 (Day 47)

Ed.: Atticus has read this. He is purring.
